Award.AwardTitle: Dissertation Research: A Novel Approach to Studying Shy-Bold Foraging Behavior in the Field: Experiments with Sunfish
Award.AbstractNarration: This study examines the factors that drive individual differences in foraging behavior within fish populations (bluegill and bass) and measures the consequences of these behaviors to juvenile growth and survival. Using novel techniques that allow individual fish to be monitored within a semi-natural pond, researchers will be able to determine the activity, habitat use, growth, diet, and survival of individually marked bluegill in the field and compare these responses to measures of shy-bold foraging behavior assessed in the laboratory. There is growing evidence that many species of animals exhibit individual differences in behaviors as a result of a tradeoff between growth and survival: for example, bold individuals may have higher feeding rates and growth rates, but also suffer higher mortality. This study will be among the first to test for this tradeoff in a natural habitat, as well as measure the ecological relevance of laboratory-based behavioral measures by determining whether shy-bold behaviors measured in the laboratory are correlated and consistent through time in a field context. This study has significant broader impacts, as the focal species (bluegill sunfish and largemouth bass) are two of the most important sport fish in the U.S. and the results of this research will help inform the better management of these species with regard to how variation in foraging behaviors impact juvenile growth, survival and vulnerability to recreational angling. The work enhances research training opportunities for undergraduates working on the project as well as the Ph.D. student directing this research. Participation by the Ph.D. student in two ongoing, NSF-funded K-12 projects will more broadly disseminate the results of this research through the development and use of inquiry-based science modules in local school classrooms.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Broader Impacts: 

This study has significant broader impacts, as the focal species (bluegill sunfish) and their predators (largemouth bass) are two of the most important sport fish in the U.S. The methods and ideas resulting from this funding will help inform better management of fish species regarding habitat use, movement, social dynamics and variation in foraging behaviors, which can all impact juvenile growth, survival and vulnerability to recreational angling. The work enhanced research training opportunities for undergraduates working on the project as well as the Ph.D. student directing this research. Concepts and results from this project have been disseminated broadly through the Ph.D. student’s participation in two ongoing K-12 projects that bring inquiry-based research into local school classrooms. Additionally, a Data Nugget (activity that promotes the use of real data in classrooms to increase student K-12 quantitative reasoning), was developed from this study and is accessible at datanuggets.org. 

Intellectual Merit:

PIT (passive integrated transponder) tag antenna systems are often used in fisheries management to follow the movement of species such as migrating salmon. These PIT tag antenna systems may also provide a powerful tool for monitoring individual fish behaviors without interference or disturbance under research situations. For example, PIT tag antenna systems can be used to examine how individual fish utilize habitats or move within a water body. Also, social dynamics, such as schooling, can be examined in a non-disruptive manner by examining groups of tags that are read together simultaneously at a specific site.  However, to date, the transfer of this technology to study fish (or other organisms) in behavioral research has been minimal. Commercially produced PIT tag antenna systems are available, but the cost to individual researchers is often prohibitive ($5,000-$10,000). Our study developed a more cost-effective system, which brings the production costs down to approximately $1,000, allowing researchers to deploy multiple antennas and data loggers to monitor fish movements in observational and experimental studies.   

For this project, we were able to design an antenna system capable of 1) examining behavioral differences in habitat use, schooling, and movement, 2) being used in water bodies such as lakes instead of streams and 3) reading the smallest PIT tags, which are designed to accommodate studies with juvenile fish. These three objectives are quite different from the current use of antennas in stream environments to track presence/absence or one-directional movement of fish species. Methods developed under this grant will facilitate further research in study systems within and outside of fisheries management.
